engagementHook.title: The Cell's Highway System
engagementHook.content: Every second, your pancreatic beta cells release 1 million insulin molecules. Each insulin molecule starts as a string of amino acids at a ribosome, then travels through a maze of membranes, gets folded, modified, packaged, and finally secreted. How does the cell ensure each protein reaches its correct destination? And what happens if this trafficking system breaks down?

keyConcepts.definition: Network of membranes with ribosomes attached. Synthesises proteins destined for secretion, membranes, or lysosomes.
No ribosomes. Synthesises lipids, steroids, phospholipids. Detoxifies drugs in liver cells. Stores calcium in muscle cells.
Stack of flattened cisternae. Modifies, packages, and sorts proteins. Cis face receives from ER; trans face ships to destinations.
Membrane-bound vesicle containing hydrolytic enzymes. pH ~5 (acidic). Digests macromolecules, worn organelles, pathogens.
Small membrane sac that carries proteins between ER, Golgi, and plasma membrane. Buds from donor, fuses with acceptor.
Route: RER → ER-Golgi intermediate compartment → cis-Golgi → medial-Golgi → trans-Golgi → secretory vesicle → exocytosis.

misconceptions.correction: Proteins are MADE at ribosomes (on rough ER or free in cytoplasm). The Golgi MODIFIES and PACKAGES proteins that were already synthesised.
Lysosomes recycle WORN-OUT organelles (autophagy) and digest pathogens. Healthy components are protected. Lysosomal enzymes are inactive until inside lysosome.
Different vesicle types have different protein coats (COPII for ER→Golgi, COPI for Golgi→ER, clathrin for Golgi→lysosome/plasma membrane).

contentSections.title: The Endomembrane System
contentSections.content: The endomembrane system is a group of membranes and organelles that work together to modify, package, and transport lipids and proteins. It includes the nuclear envelope, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, vesicles, and plasma membrane. These compartments are connected either directly (nuclear envelope-ER) or by transport vesicles.
keyPoints: Nuclear envelope and ER are continuous (connected membranes)
ER and Golgi communicate via vesicles
contentSections.example: Insulin synthesis: mRNA translated on RER → enters ER lumen → vesicle to Golgi → modified and packaged → secretory vesicle → exocytosis.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why must lysosomal enzymes pass through the ER and Golgi before reaching lysosomes?

contentSections.title: Rough ER vs Smooth ER

items: Synthesises proteins for secretion or membranes
Abundant in cells making proteins (e.g., plasma B cells)
Abundant in liver cells, steroid-producing cells

contentSections.note: Both are continuous with nuclear envelope and share the same internal space (lumen).
contentSections.example: Rough ER in pancreatic cells produces digestive enzymes. Smooth ER in liver detoxifies alcohol. Smooth ER in muscle (sarcoplasmic reticulum) stores calcium.

contentSections.title: Golgi Apparatus and Lysosome Formation
contentSections.content: The Golgi apparatus is the cell's packaging and distribution centre. Proteins arrive at the cis face in vesicles from the ER, then pass through cisternae where they're modified. At the trans face, proteins are sorted into vesicles bound for different destinations. Lysosomes form when vesicles containing hydrolytic enzymes bud from the trans-Golgi. These enzymes are tagged with mannose-6-phosphate (M6P) receptors to ensure they go to lysosomes, not secretion.
keyPoints: Cisternae are NOT connected; proteins move by vesicles
M6P tag ensures lysosomal enzymes reach lysosomes
contentSections.example: I-cell disease: Missing M6P tagging enzyme → lysosomal enzymes secreted instead of retained. Causes skeletal abnormalities and developmental delay.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: What would happen if a lysosomal enzyme didn't have the M6P tag?

multipleChoice.question: A protein destined for secretion from the cell would pass through which compartments in order?
options: Golgi → Rough ER → Lysosome → Plasma membrane
Rough ER → Golgi → Secretory vesicle → Plasma membrane
Smooth ER → Golgi → Rough ER → Plasma membrane
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Rough ER → Golgi → Secretory vesicle → Plasma membrane
multipleChoice.rationale: Secretory proteins are synthesised on rough ER, modified in Golgi, packaged into secretory vesicles, then released by exocytosis. Lysosomes are for digestion, not secretion.

multipleChoice.question: Which of the following is a function of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum?
multipleChoice.rationale: Smooth ER lacks ribosomes and synthesises lipids/steroids. Liver SER detoxifies drugs. Protein synthesis is rough ER; packaging is Golgi; waste breakdown is lysosomes.

multipleChoice.question: The mannose-6-phosphate (M6P) tag is important because it:
options: Targets proteins to the plasma membrane
Identifies proteins destined for the nucleus
multipleChoice.rationale: M6P receptors in trans-Golgi bind M6P-tagged enzymes and package them into vesicles bound for lysosomes. Without M6P, lysosomal enzymes would be secreted (as in I-cell disease).

shortAnswer.question: Explain the difference between the cis and trans faces of the Golgi apparatus, including their positions relative to other organelles. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Cis face is the receiving side; faces the ER and receives transport vesicles
1 mark: Trans face is the shipping side; faces the plasma membrane
1 mark: Proteins enter cis, are modified through cisternae, exit from trans to various destinations
shortAnswer.commonError: Confusing which face receives vs ships; not mentioning relative positions

definitions: Rough ER: Membrane network with ribosomes; synthesises and folds proteins.
Smooth ER: No ribosomes; makes lipids, detoxifies, stores calcium.
Golgi apparatus: Stack of cisternae; modifies, packages, sorts proteins.
Cis face: Receiving side (near ER); trans face: shipping side (near membrane).
Lysosome: Vesicle with digestive enzymes; breaks down macromolecules.
M6P tag: Mannose-6-phosphate marker directs enzymes to lysosomes.
keyPoints: Secretory pathway: RER → Golgi → vesicles → secretion
Rough ER makes proteins; smooth ER makes lipids
Lysosomal enzymes need M6P tag to reach lysosomes
Vesicles bud from donor, fuse with acceptor membrane
diagrams: Endomembrane system overview showing flow between compartments
Golgi cis/trans faces with transport directions

shortAnswer: The cis face of the Golgi apparatus is the receiving side, positioned facing the endoplasmic reticulum. It receives transport vesicles containing proteins from the rough ER. The trans face is the shipping side, facing the plasma membrane, from which proteins leave in vesicles bound for their final destinations (lysosomes, plasma membrane, or secretion). Proteins are modified as they pass from cis through medial to trans cisternae.
